title: Boy, 12, electrocuted on rail line as friend screamed 'help me, don't leave me'
text:

A 12-year-old boy who was electrocuted on live train tracks last night in Bootle has been pictured for the first time.

James Myers managed to clamber onto the high voltage train network at around 7pm last night.

A witness earlier described the horrific moment shortly after the incident he heard the boy's friend screaming from the tracks: "help me, help me, mister!

"Don't leave me!"

James has been described by neighbours as "a lovely kid" who "always had a smile on his face," reports the Liverpool ECHO.

(Image: Julian Hamilton/Daily Mirror)

The Everton fan was with a friend, also 12, when he got onto the train line.

Neighbour Jimmy Ellison was walking his dog in the area when he came across James' desperate 12-year-old friend.

The 65-year-old said: "I could hear this kid, shouting, and then I saw him jump down off the bridge.

"He was saying, "help me, help me, mister!

"Don't leave me!"

The youngster, the retired window cleaner said, was "in hysterics" and was still in his school uniform.

(Image: Julian Hamilton/Daily Mirror)

The married dad-of-four added: "I never saw the lad.

"The boy said he had a phone, and jumped down onto the subway floor.

"I told him, "you dial the number and I'll talk to them. I talked to the police on the phone.

"When they arrived they[officers] were all on top of the bridge and they had a small torch while they were looking as it was dark.

"Then the firefighters turned up with their big lights so we could see better. Everywhere was cordoned off.

"The lad got taken into the police car - he said he was just 12. Police spoke to me and then said I could go.

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

"I haven't stopped crying all night."

Mr Ellison said the boy told him the lads had returned to that section of railway line to retrieve something which they had lost on the track last weekend.

He said he heard possibly one train go past while James was on the line, and he quickly implored police to cut the electricity off, he added.

He added: "I was a nervous wreck. It's tragic, it really is."

Police say they don't believe there aren't any suspicious circumstances involved in the incident.

They are appealing to anyone who may have seen two young boys in the area around the time of the incident to get in touch.

Today, shocked friends paid tribute to James, describing him as a "happy-go-lucky lad" who was the middle of three brothers.

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

On social media, his older brother posted a picture of his sibling, where many pals spoke of the well-liked Newfield School pupil in Thornton.

At the scene in Bootle, a little Everton FC teddy bear was pinned to the railings where the tragedy took place.

Just yards from the spot where James was killed, his girlfriend, aged 14, left a floral tribute on the railings , which was brought down by the "devastated" girl's mum.

Quoting from the words of a Rhianna song, Diamond, she wrote: "Shine bright like a diamond.

"You were the happiest little boy. You will be missed. By your girl."

Friends who knew James well described him as an "amazing lad whose smile would light up the room".

One said: "He was always so polite. He was a bouncy little lad."

One friend told the ECHO: "I've known James for years, he's one of my little brother's best friends.

"He was a happy-go-lucky lad, and everyone would look out for him.

"He was very energetic, and never had any fears in his life."

"I feel for his mum and dad so much, it's shocking.

(Image: LIVERPOOL ECHO)

"His older brother, is heartbroken."

Neighbour Sonia Melton, 33, said her 11-year-old son was friends with the boy who died.

She said: "We're in bits, my heart goes out to his mum.

"He was a lovely kid, they're all lovely kids round here. My son used to play out with him."

Ms Melton bought red roses and said she would take her son to leave them as a tribute once he was home from school.

One man, who is close to James' older brother, added: "James was never scared of anything, but he was a sensible lad, who was doing well in school.

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

"What's happened is such a shame, something must have crossed his mind [to make him venture onto the tracks].

"Last night, his brother rang me, crying, and said, I think he's dead.

"I went to see him, he was in a state...he doesn't know what to do.

"All I can do is support him and be there for him as much as I can.

"Something needs to be done about safety on the tracks...he[James] must have jumped over.

"I've seen kids up at Seaforth jumping on the tracks..why is nothing done to stop them?

"It's really upsetting.

"It's heartbreaking, we have lost a good soul."

"He always had a smile on his face and it made us love him even more.

"Little James, bless him, something must have crossed his mind.

"He was energetic, and was always in a big group of friends."

Network Rail, who manage the railway where the tragedy happened, said they had launched an immediate investigation.

Police probing the death described it as a "incredibly tragic incident."

In an updated statement, the British Transport Police said: "We can confirm that a 12-year-old boy sadly died on the railway in Bootle, Merseyside last night.

"Officers from British Transport Police were called to the lines in Bootle shortly after 7pm last night following reports of a casualty on the tracks.

"Paramedics from the North West Ambulance service also attended, and a 12-year-old boy from the local area was sadly pronounced dead at the scene.

"His injuries were consistent with electrocution and the incident is not being treated as suspicious.

"The boy’s family have been informed and are being supported by specially trained family liaison officers."

Detective Chief Inspector Steve Lewis said: “This is an incredibly tragic incident which I know will have shocked many in the local community.

“I would like to extend my deepest condolences to the boy’s family and request that they are given the space and privacy they need to come to terms with this devastating loss.

If you can help, text 61016 or call 0800 40 50 40 quoting reference 488 of 14/10/19.
description: A friend of James Myers, 12, screamed for help before the youngster died on the railway line in Bootle , Merseyside
